Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Boston is an urban setting with plenty of part time work opportunities
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: always helping prepare for future
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: BU has a great job board website which has helped me obtain two jobs thus far. I can only imagine that the alumni network is strong, but I have yet to experience that.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Tuition is too high, but there job prospects, alumni, and career services are good.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: As a science student, research has been difficult to come by. While there are opportunities out there, they are difficult to secure considering science students already have  difficult, demanding and full schedules.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: While applying to the online graduate program I'm in, I had an advisor who I talked with frequently. In the program, I have an advisor and the program administrator who are incredibly helpful for providing information and help whenever students need it. As far as on-campus services, seeing as I am an online graduate student, I am personally unaware of how they are rated but have heard good things about them.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: The CDC is very helpful and I've attended multiple career fairs to help me with internship search and such.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I feel absolutely certain I will be able to get any job or position I desire with a degree from BU. The research and internship opportunities are incredible and provide incomperable opportunities to prepare students for whatever their dreams may be.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: As a freshman, I have already had the opportunity to apply for about 3 different summer internships, and I am grateful for that opportunity.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The center for career development is very helpful
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I did not do much in the way of career development or internship yet because being in CGS means that I have not declared a major yet and have so far only taken an intro course for the school I want to continue into. I think by the end of my sophomore year I will have a better idea of what kind of career I want to look for and then will use the resources available to help me choose the right path to a career. BU's career center reaches out to students on a monthly basis by email, so it is a great resource that is present in stundents' minds.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I ended up getting a job right after graduation
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: My degree at BU will guarantee me a job!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The school is very helpful with internships and jobs. I haven't taken full advantage of these facilities, yet, but I have many friends who were satisfied with the experience. I haven't seen many employers recruiting on campus, but that's probably because I'm a freshman and they typically don't target people my age. I haven't heard much about an alumni network, though BU has several famous alumni.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Jobs should be easy to come by with a BU degree
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I found out that many people respect BU very much. Having great alumni like Martin Luther King and Owen Young gives us students a very privileged standing. Also, finding a job after getting a degree is fairly easy.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Our career center is amazing and I know I'll be all set when I graduate. I've had internships every year, very easy to find them and huge network of helpful alums.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I went to the school of management and everyone I know got jobs.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Value of a degree is good because of the big name.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I hear there is a great alumni presence but I don't know much beyond that. I often get emails abut job/internship opportunities.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I haven't experienced much of this yet, but I know there are options
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I honestly have not looked that much into this. I should.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: There are so many opportunities and resources, but you need to apply yourself to actually using these resources. This isn't a restaurant where you order your future and it comes on a silver platter.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: It seems like it will be quite manageable to find a job after graduating, but there is a lot of competition.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Lots of career fairs. Each school within BU does a great job connecting students to jobs or internships and making sure they inform these students of the opportunities.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The career center/ services on campus really have a lot of resources to help students in the job process.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The Center for Career Development offers a lot of services to try and help students.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: If you're a business student at BU, you'll make a lot of connections and you WILL have a job when you graduate. COM, SED, and the School of Engineering are very good about preparing people for the job market as well. No degree from BU looks bad, and we're ranked very highly nationally and internationally in terms of employment after graduation. The Career Center is also a good resource, and they offer a great class for seniors who are looking for jobs. BU also looks good on grad school apps, though grad school isn't very affordable after paying BU tuition.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: BU's physical therapy program is highly respected, especially with all of the clinical time.  I feel positive about career prospects.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Very good place to graduate from and very helpful towards helping students plan their future
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: there are plenty of opportunities to meet potential employers
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Only prospects are from the school name and career fairs
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: The Career and resource center definitely reaches out to students to come and get help building resumes and cover letters and getting connected to jobs/ internships. Some of the colleges/ specific program advisors will also offer additional practicums and internships. BU is such a big, successful school right in Boston, so there are countless opportunities to take advantage of in terms of the law firms, hospitals, engineering companies, tech startups, labs, etc. and also in terms of networking. Overall, BU definitely gives you opportunities to continue a stable career after graduation; it is more a matter of how much you take advantage of what is offered, because advisors and the Resource center are not always going to hold your hand and remind you to check in with them.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: As a freshman, I haven't had much experience with applying for real internships/jobs yet. However I know that our school has a great Center for Career Development, and an online service for finding part time jobs/ research opportunities.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Our career development center is great, and I believe that a degree from BU will get you many places.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I have heard from many in the field that a degree from BU will open many doors.  The opportunities for internships is great and I look forward to when I get to that point.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: There is less career support for the arts from the university, but the professors are extremely helpful with internships. It is difficult to have an internship during the semester due to course schedules, school commitments, and workload.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I hope the degree is worth something because it is such a large investment, I feel I will be able to use it later though
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: BU has a very diverse network of alumnus and career center that can help you for after school.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I can't speak for all of Boston University, but at Questrom (the business school) it's almost impossible not to get internship or job prospects.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I haven't looked too much into career and job perspectives yet, although I should. From what I can tell from my friends, it's a pretty active environment. A couple times a year there are job fairs where employers come and look for prospective employees, and students go in formal interview wear and bring their resumes. One of my friends got an internship summer after freshman year, and another has a very good job waiting for her when she graduates, and she's been promised this position for almost a year. Our Center for Career Development (CCD) is very helpful. They hold seminars and workshops on general topics like how to put together a resume to more specific topics like what careers you can go into with a degree in psychology. You can also make appointments with the CCD to talk to someone one on one about whatever questions or problems you have.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: For the education program there is a very high employment rate and I've heard great things about the career services center, though I haven't actually been there.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: BU has really good name recognition abroad as well as within the US. Coming from China everyone down to relatively uneducated people had heard of the school before which is a plus. It was also sighted by one the bosses I had at a summer internship as one of the things that made my resume stand out. Overall I feel like BU was a good choice for helping me get a job due to the name recognition.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: We have a wonderful career student center which has innumerable connections that can easily connect you to the perfect internship or job afterward. The value of having a degree from the school is priceless because it is very helpful with having such great name recognition. It makes the job application all the more valuable and stand out all the more.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I'll have a valuable degree with job opportunities when I graduate.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The degree from BU is one that looks very good when applying for jobs, and BU graduates are very employable. The school also has good resources for students, you just have to look for them on your own.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: From what I've heard, a degree from Boston University is very helpful when trying to find a job later in life. The school does offer a lot of research and internship opportunities as well.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I think that BU is such a high ranked university that many employers will not turn us down.  I have worked in the alumni relations office this past semester, and so many people are willing to support BU because of how much success they have achieved from graduating from the University. BU offers amazing help with job and internship placements.  I recently applied for a job on the BU jobs website and was offered the job immediately after applying and interviewing.  I think that BU has amazing services that can definitely prepare me for my future outside of Boston University.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review:
First off, the Financial Aid Office's customer service is great. Always remember they mean well and want to help, even when the numbers are higher than you expected. They will almost always waive the late fee, as long as you're communicating. They understand our pain as students because they all were there. My 2 star rating is not intended for them!

But really, it's just stingy BU. They don't award much money, especially if your parents filed a tax return extension and BU has to wait around until August for your tax information. However, that part is out of their control because money runs out. Can't argue that one, only can complain. Graduating with debt (usually more than a few thousand dollars) is just a part of the culture here. I should add that I know one or two people here on full scholarship, but this is usually merit-based rather than need-based. Unless you have the money stashed away or you won a full scholarship, you will probably run around looking for money. My real question is: why can we afford smart phones and pretty laptops but not an education?

MY ADVICE, and please take this advice: Start early!! Don't wait until you're packing for college to look for scholarships--more importantly, don't wait until you're in college. Apply to everything that comes your way. Take surveys like this one, write essays, and enter no-essay scholarship contests daily! Even, or especially, the $100-$600 contests. Just because you run into $10,000 scholarships doesn't rule out the little guys. Those may mean tens of thousands of dollars. To all high schoolers planning on attending college, those tuition bills are coming way sooner than you think, and there is SO much money out there, all you have to do is write a few short essays.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The process is easy, just submit FAFSA, PROFILE, and IDOC. Problem is the cutoff for merit scholarships is very high for a school with such rampant grade deflation.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The financial aid office at BU is extremely helpful so I recommend calling with any questions you have because the documents can sometimes be a hassle to fill out! Just make sure to get everything in by the deadlines!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I received a $20,000 per year scholarship without applying.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I would appreciate more financial aid.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Public Health financial aid is a little different, and the staff aren't always friendly to communicate with!
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: They don't have many scholarships for people based on academic success.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: BU will provide a little, but don't expect a lot
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I didn't receive much financial aid. Instead of the emailing the financial aid office, I encourage students to go to the office in person.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Maybe it's just my financial situation, but I didn't get any.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: BU is expensive and there is no way getting around it.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I got grants. Scholarships are hard to come by unless you're really smart and need it. Plus theres a lot of wealth at BU so not everyone needs it.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I was awarded certain financial aid and I have received it. Much of my worries come from the general financial mishaps of the American education system. I need more financial aid than I have received but that's because getting a higher education in the US is extremely expensive. This is an issue that goes much further than just this one university.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It's nothing spectacular or horrible. I'd say the process is pretty average and I wouldn't know any tips to getting aid. The people in the financial office are really slow to respond.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: BU is pretty expensive but they offer a ton of aid and scholarships to athletes, good students, and people gifted in certain fields. Also, loan programs are good here.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The school is incredibly helpful with finding you an internship. There are multiple career fairs and networking events throughout the year.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Most people don't get scholarships. A lot of people receive loans; it just depends on your situation.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: BU is so expensive that even with financial aid packages that sound nice, it's still really expensive. With that being said.. BU was still the cheapest school out of many that I got accepted to!
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Once you get them, the scholarships and loans can be extremely helpful. Getting them is an entirely different matter. It's usually a hassle, with BU telling you repeatedly that some part of the submission of documents was not absolutely perfect. Huge headaches!!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I did not receive as much aid as I needed, with two current college students in the family, but I did receive aid.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I didnt get a lot of money.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I definitely wish I would have gotten more financial aid, but I filed pretty late in the process. The staff was incredibly helpful, and they really helped me out.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: For the academic school year, it was very smooth. You just turn in the FAFSA and Profile and other information they need and as long as you have a real need for it you will get aid. Keep in mind however that they're stingy in a lot of other things like there are a lot of random fees and such as you go through your college experience, but it's like that at most colleges. Also, if you want to study abroad over the summer for example, you're essentially on your own in terms of financial aid. There is some, but not lots. Studying abroad during the year on the other hand your aid transfers and sometimes means is cheaper to go abroad than to live on campus.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: There aren't many scholarships but there are a lot of need based grants. Even though I received academic scholarships from most colleges I applied to but not BU, the grants made BU much more affordable in the end.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: There's a deadline you can apply by to be considered for a scholarship so that's awesome. Other than that it's all need based and BU is pretty fair with what your capable of.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: You have to basically be a genius to get a merit scholarship. I was top 5% of my 320 person class and didn't get a dime. Financial aid isn't great either. One thing you learn very quickly is that BU loves to take your money.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I don't own a car.  When my parents drive to visit, finding a parking space on campus can be a bit of a challenge. they usually opt. for street parking and/or private parking.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The school always sends me e-mails about opportunities, such as intership, part-time jobs, or sometimes full-time jobs. Thanks to those e-mails, I was able to save my time looking for those opportunities. My aunt and cousin graduated from BU, and they both told me that alumni network of BU is indeed the best in Massachusetts. I do part-time job in the campus, and the pay is great!!
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: They have issues with out-of-state information.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It's difficult to get enough money to pay for college.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Appeal your financial aid just in case, it may be worth it
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Accepted offer for after graduation, variety of internships every summer - BU (at least SMG) does a great job of placing the most successful students, and pretty much everyone will find a job without much trouble
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: I got a little bit of music scholarship I was happy with.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: its kk wit de muney
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: I am quite upset with Boston University's Financial Aid System. I don't understand how a university with so much money has very limited options for financial aid. They don't have much money to help students attend and cover the high costs.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I'm not sure how many scholarships are given. I did not receive any. I think it is pretty hard to get a scholarship.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: It's pretty easy to deal with the financial aid office, but I did not receive all the financial aid I needed
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: BU is pretty stingy on financial aid in my experience. Even when I appealed my award package, they didn't give me more. Overall a pretty expensive school that I don't think is worth the price tag.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: BU is really into networking and placing their students in internships. There are SO MANY resources available. The Educational Resource Center is a great place to go for career advice and help
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: School is very highly rated for BioE majors. Many research opportunities and internships.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I need financial aid, but my calculated family contribution is too high. I am working on getting merit scholarships.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: You either get all the money or none.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: BU messed up my financial aid package due to lateness and missing documentations, disqualifying me for work study. I barely have enough money.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: No chance of international students getting any kinds of awards at all.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: BU has a great job acceptance rate. This only gets better in the School of Management and my specific major of Finance.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: BU is a private school and as such is very pricey. It's hard to find the money you need.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: While I received a great deal of aid in my first year, I lost most of it after my dad got a new job-- so watch out for that.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It's a VERY expensive school, so therefore people like me who need a lot of aid don't always get enough to cover what they owe. I'm going to be paying off loans to BU for a LONG LONGGGGG time, but it was well worth the experience and memories I had there!
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Big school, bigger alumni network. Always opportunity for internships and employment.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I've heard a lot of students get financial aid, but I've had general trouble and haven't received any aid.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: still trying to get more
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The financial aid coordinator of my program is the nicest lady who is always prompt in replying to my questions, and she never hesitates to have me come in so she can answer specific concerns that I have. I didn't receive as much aid as I would have liked, considering how expensive Boston University is, but I hope that in the long run it will be worth it.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: My school continues to increase tuition and I'm still paying a lot when the semester ends and the bill comes. I don't understand why the financial aid isn't increased significantly so that students can see that the school cares about us and our education and not just the money we are paying. Tuition is very expensive and there needs to be more loans, scholarships, and help for students. I also think that the tuition should be lowered so students won't be burdened. Especially when senior year comes and all the tuition has to be paid before they can graduate/get a diploma. Too many obstacles!
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: You have to find the right person to talk to, then you can get what you want done.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: i don't have many tips for financial aid... luckily i got a merit scholarship
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: BU is actually pretty generous with financial aid so long as you have stellar grades AND turn in all your fin aid forms on time.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I had a hard time receiving aid due to the cost of attendance of the school.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: I have many friends who received pretty much full rides. I got the basic financial aid, and I know for my rich white annoying roommate she didnt need financial aid whatsoever
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: For its endowment, aid and scholarships through BU is absolutely pitiful
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I am fortunate enough to receive some financial aid from the school, but it is not a very large portion of the bill. I know people who have had to transfer because BU is too expensive and they were not offered any financial aid at all. The process itself is not too bad, but if you want to dispute the package they do or do not offer, it is not easy. I would suggest getting the forms in as soon as possible because it is first come first serviced and don't forget to reapply each year.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It can be hard to get someone on the phone during peak season after acceptances but they will work with you
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: BU is pretty stingy when it comes to financial aid for middle class families.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: They are great on giving you loans, not very good on scholarships and one year they reduced my scholarship.  Financial Aid is the only thing at BU that makes me wish I had studied elsewhere.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: BU's academic aid is great, in terms of financial aid- still better than many other schools, but I think financial aid in general is a hassle to get.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: They don't want to give you  money.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I got a good merit aid award, but as the price of the school goes up, my family and I are definitely struggling.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I have friends that have financial aid. Some wish they had more, but others believe they have a great amount.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I did not get any financial aid. A lot of my friends did, however, and many of them have work-study jobs at BU.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Pretty average experience getting aid. For such an expensive school it's a necessity for most people and a headache, but they were helpful enough.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I was fortunate enough to not have to apply for financial aid for my first semester, plus since I originally registered as a non-matriculating student, I was not eligible to apply. For the 2014-2015 semester I will be applying for financial aid. So far my experience has been positive. Someone from financial aid came to one of our classes and explained how to apply for financial aid, explained the FAFSA form, and were are also sent emails about upcoming scholarships, deadlines, and what websites to access for scholarships.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review:
Not the best:( I am hoping to at least get the same package this fall. I will have some very serious loans. 

I was unable to find work due to my school schedule, applied to anything and everything but no one wants to hire someone who only has 1 or 2 free hours available everyday at different times. I think the University can do slightly better with aid packages.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I received a good amount of scholarship, but not enough
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Generally, they meet ones needs.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The only thing is dealing with it each year based on my parents financial situation which is different each year.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: They need to work on giving out more.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: You either get the scholarships or you don't. It seems pretty random too. I got full tuition while others got nothing. It's just how it goes.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I did receive a rather large merit scholarship, but I didn't receive much need-based aid. For such an expensive school, I would have hoped to receive more aid. If you need a scholarship, definitely apply for the merit ones with admission because they don't give out very many for continuing students.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: School is stingy.. can't get anything out of them
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: barely give any aid. very expensive tuition
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: This school is okay with financial aid, but considering I'm still applying for scholarships, they must not be perfect. Financial Aid is good for covering school costs, but as a student living away from home, in another state there are other things I need to have and financial aid, including work study, doesn't really hep with that.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Most importantly get all your information in to the school by the deadlines.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I received a merit-based scholarship (The Presidential Scholarship) worth $10,000/ semester. Without this scholarship I would not be able to attend Boston University.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: BU offers a good amount of scholarship, but it is an expensive school, so obviously I would have liked to have received more. They are pretty reasonable in my experience. I've heard mixed things from other people.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I am convinced Financial aid is a pain where ever you may end up. I have been lucky enough to receive plenty of aid, however it takes mountains of "paperwork" (online) and a few visits to the office every semester.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review:
Boston University is expensive. They give out some financial aid, but not that much. Unless you are a super genius or a minority, you will not be getting a lot of money from the school. You will most likely be given what will get you to come to BU but not without your parents struggling to scrape together the funds.

If you write a letter to financial aid, they may give you a bit more, but not a lot.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The school is insanely expensive and offers grants based SOLELY on academic performance. Helloooo I am poor! I need assistance.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I applied and received the full need I demonstrated
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: My circumstances are different. Never needed to apply for financial aid until now.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: My experience has been tough. Tuition rising doesn't necessarily mean aid rising. Tips: apply as early as possible and talk to someone in detail about your package.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: I didn't really get all of the aid I actually need. I'm looking into transferring because BU is just way too expensive.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It was ok, but I had to contact them a few times to smooth things out
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: I did not receive any financial aid from BU.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: They are not the best at giving out scholarships.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: It would've been nice if they had offered more scholarship opportunities that weren't so specialized in one focus or another. The financial aid wasn't much, and I still had to take out loans.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I received a small scholarship from BU, not due to my financial situation but due to my performances from the previous college I attended to. The odd things is that part of the scholarship was a housing scholarship so it half forces you to live on campus. Also I wasn't offered a financial aid from FASFA grants which was odd because the school I attended before had lower tuition and I was still offered.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Not great financial aid, they have some scholarships but they are mainly targeted towards freshman. BU is just very expensive so make sure its 100% where you want to be to get your moneys worth.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I had to fight tooth and nail for every penny I got from BU, but in the end they helped out my family an INCREDIBLE amount.  They continue to be supportive of my academic goals and always are available for questions regarding financial aid and respond in a timely and professional manner.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: They say they give out scholarships, but ask any current BU students...  People will say BU is squeezing the money out of student's pocket. BU doesn't have much endowments, but all the money to build new buildings and all sorts of "projects" come from the student's tuition. I know I sound really bitter, but the stingy financial aid is one of the reasons I'm doing surveys to perhaps continue my college education.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: I received a good amount of financial aid and was very fortunate however it was and is still a struggle to pay the bill.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Financial aid at BU is generally generous in comparison to other schools and you get a comparable package in following years as long as there have been no drastic changes to your financial situation. Considering how expensive BU is, the financial aid office is generally willing to work with you. You can also appeal your package which sometimes leads to more aid. However, there was an article saying that BU makes it hard for students who need the aid to attend and instead give it to smart/impressive students who don't need the money as badly to persuade them to attend.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I wish I had received more financial aid, but the amount that I did receive was easy to get.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review:
Being an international student I had minimal options available for financial aid. The procedure to obtain the funds was not very complex, but the amount is very restricted as compared to the cost for tuition. 
I suggest the school should have more financial aid options for international students, or some options equivalent to the work-study program.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: I recieved an okay amount after months and months of battling. However, I had a unique situation where paperwork got messed up. Still, it took a lot on my part. Most of my friends didn't have nearly as much hassle though.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: There are many students at BU that have scholarships and financial aid.  Apply to as many university scholarships that fit your scenario, but don't be worried if you don't receive actual scholarships!  Many students receive the necessary aid to make BU a reality - the financial aid department truly does their best to make it possible.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: BU gives me good financial aid but it's still not enough for me, given that I come from a low income family. My financial aid advisor was able to give  me more loans, not scholarships which suck because I know BC is great with that.  BU has all this money, but they can't award students with scholarships.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I didn't receive any financial aid at all. I was very disappointed because now it makes it harder for my family to send me and my two twin brothers to college.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review:
The Only Bad Thing About the School – Unfortunately, I have to pay a lot to come here. It IS worth it, but it is also a lot of money. I received very little aid, and scholarships were given out weirdly. I know some kids who received them and some who didn't, but their academic and background are almost the same. I wish I had received more money....

The office will try to help you find a job, but you should go search on your own.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: BU has been extremely generous and helpful with me. I would not have been able to afford BU on my own; however, with the help of the Financial Aid office, college has been extremely affordable.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: University Has Some Weird Policies – The University will actively seek to find new and exciting scholarships for you, but this is to make it so the university contribution to your overall financial aid can go down.  In one instance, this led to me receiving a private scholarship for $11,000, so they removed the university scholarship for $20,000.  My -$9,000 winnings weren't very helpful in the long run. This took a ridiculous amount of work to fix. The bureaucratic system actively tries to hide the person in charge of your financial aid so people can't contact them when, say, they suddenly lose $9,000 without doing anything.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: The school doesn't offer scholarships or grants as easily as other major universities did.  They make you file appeals along with all the W-2, tax returns, and explanations all over again once you file it on FAFSA and CSS Profile, which is redundant.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: It's Been a Nightmare – It's been horrible. Just because was denied my noncustodial waiver I was automatically given no aid.  And I really needed it!
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: They WILL Lose Something – I got a pretty nice reward package but still it was not enough to cover everything.  If you are not happy with the money you are getting from the school just try appealing for a better reward and you may have some luck.  During the financial aid process I ran into my share of bumps.  A couple of forms were really late or had to be sent again.  Always keep an extra copy of all forms since they are not responsible.  If you do not have copies then you are in trouble.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Apply for Need-Based – If there's even a slight chance that you might get need-based aid, apply for it. BU is huge, and has many, many qualified applicants. Merit-based scholarships are not easy to come by here, though they do happen occasionally, so don't let that keep you from applying. Apply for outside scholarships, definitely.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I've got the most scholarship and financial aid from Boston University when I applied to schools. However, I still pay alot of money because the tuition is very high (BU is a private institution).
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Ad Com – much like kafka's the castle but ultimately with more of a soul
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Helpful and Nice! BU is pretty good at meeting needs! I got a pretty good financial aid package and even though the financial aid process can be a pain, the people in the financial aid office are extremely helpful and soooo nice! BU asks for a lot during the process, so that's annoying, but if you're in need, they will help!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Surprisingly Awesome – Without scholarships I definitely wouldn't have been able to afford BU. BU met almost all of my need, offered me financial help with housing, work-study, and has s system to help you find long-term or quickie jobs. It was by far my best financial aid package.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: 57 Grand – financial aid helps a little but depends more on scholarships
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I received no financial aid whatsoever. The only way I got any money was to take out a loan.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I don't receive any financial aid, but I have friends who've managed to get a decent amount from BU and FAFSA. Be sure to file FAFSA on time.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: They Could Be a Little Less Bias – I did not receive any aid because my parents make so much yet i do so well in school. It is really unfair. I suggest that students do not stop hassling the financial aid office for every penny
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Very Generous – Very generous with financial aid if you're a deserving candidate.  Can usually appeal for a couple thousand more.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Keep your grades up in senior year! gpa is everything for financial aid when you are not qualified for help! colleges like boston university have very expensive tuitions and money is never a bad thing to gain! work on your essays and find out all scholarship information and start right away!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Appeal Appeal Appeal – Boston University allows you to appeal almost any decision, including the amount of financial aid you receive. In most cases, BU does what is can to help those who need aid.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Great Need Based – I received a decent amount of financial aid, but it was all need based. A couple of my forms got lost in the shuffle, so I had to stay on top of things. I suggest making regular in-person appointments with your financial aid officer to make sure things are going smoothly. I tried for scholarships but i was informed it wouldnt change my overall package. My friend couldnt get any financial aid at all (the only option he was left with was outside scholarships).
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Don't Know of a Lot – Don't know how to get a lot, but generally BU gives a fair amount of scholarships even though it also costs a fair amount.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I received the financial aid I needed and the process was very easy.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: BU is actually pretty bad with its bureaucracy, and it's not unknown to revoke scholarships and aid. It does cut down a good amount of the costs, but you have to have a little fire in you to stay on top of things and make sure that they don't deny you loans or aid you did in fact earn. You will most likely have to make multiple phone calls and emails, but they are typically rewarding in the end. PS scholarships are almost always given to freshmen who send in their applications before a deadline that can only be found in small print - BEWARE! However, they still give aid even if you don't make it.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Many of the awards are only granted upon admission to the school, and I was initially overlooked. After an appeal, however, I received a solid amount of money, but you cannot earn these awards later as you progress through BU. If you're unhappy with what you receive initially, definitely appeal the decision. The worst that can happen is that they don't give you any more money. BU has an alleged reputation for being stingy. The scholarships within each professional school are helpful, but I'm not sure how selective they are/how many people apply for them, but I know that I plan on applying for them.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Show Me the Money – Received hardly any financial aid, repeal letter was denied. Wondering how to pay for future years here
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Needs Work – The process itself is just a lot of paperwork. The big problem with financial aid stuff is that the school doesn't have much to offer when it comes to scholarships. The people are friendly and are a good help, but it's sometimes hard for them to communicate.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Money to Blow – BU has a lot of money. A lot. Getting your information in in a timely manner is key. Make sure that you are not forgetting something each time you go in. Do it right the first time so that little distractions such as forgetting to fill out some paper work will not shy you away from your goal of getting aid. If they do not give money that you want, go in and speak to them Let them see your passion. Make sure to FOLLOW UP! Very important. The money is there though.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Greedy Bastards – They will almost never give any aid or scholarships. All they seem to care about is taking every penny from you. The process was arduous and they will not do anything to help students. I am leaving because of their unrelenting greed.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: So far I've seen a lot of reviews that say most kids are very rich and there isn't a lot of financial aid. I have yet to meet many kids who are paying full, except for international students. Granted, even with financial aid, some people still pay a good chunk of money. However, the school is pretty generous with merit based aid, but you have to work hard to maintain an adequate gpa or you might lose scholarships.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: You can get what you want if youre willing to pay but most things close early
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Definately and all dining points plan would be the best
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There aren't a lot of student discounts, but options are great. The food is overall really good.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: The food isn't the greatest. The new dining hall – Marciano is pretty okay, but like I mentioned above, they try to be too "fancy"
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Boston is a city filled with food of all sorts, so I'm taking "off-campus" as the surrounding city. From BU, you could walk to Brookline, to Newbury St and Boylston, to Fenway Park, and even over the bridge to Cambridge. If you can imagine the food you are looking for, you will find it. The only problem is that Boston gets so much snow that you wouldn't want to travel very far and are limited to Panera, coffee shops, convenience stores, and a couple Asian restaurants. I'm probably missing a few but it's not tooo much.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Just too pricey, another thing that I wish I just hadn't done so I could save money. HOWEVER, if you are in an apartment, get the $500 (or $1000) apartment plan! You receive that money in points, which you can use on B&N textbooks, printing, food, whatever. AND you get 80 (or 160) meals for free. So worth it. And quite honestly, the one great deal I found at BU.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Boston is our campus so anything off campus would mean venturing further into the city to get food which is just amazing.  Boston is a cultural hub so any of the food you get is probably going to be worth your while (just maybe a tad bit more expensive).
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dude. It's Boston. There's a ridiculous amount of options. If you can think of a kind of food, you can get it somewhere in the city. Prices not the best.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Plenty of options but i wish dining halls had more variety
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The food on campus may seem to get a bit repetitive after a while but generally it is very good.  I went to visit a friend at another college and I was extremely disappointed with their food. We actually have it really good when it comes to food!  I recommend using your meal plan before paying for your own stuff!  You have the plan for a reason! Try something new!!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: You're in Boston. If you can't find someplace to eat, you have a more serious issue.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Bay State is excellent. It was recently rated the best dining hall in America.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Tons of choices, many open late or offering alternative diets. A good selection but not too much for really cheap options.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Tons of great restaurants all around Boston. It can get pricy!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: In general the food is pretty good, although some days are better than others
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Boston has great food in general, lots of variety
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: BU dining is very good compared to other schools
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are great off campus dining options and they're worth going to
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Honestly, Boston University has one of the better dining halls. The food can be bland from time to time, but I'd much rather have bland food than greasy and unhealthy eating options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I haven't been to many places, but there are a lot of them. You are in Boston, tons of food options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The food is good for a dining hall and great at bay state. As a rule, Warren serves pizza and then some combination of a country and chicken as a dish.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: When you're in Boston, you won't have any trouble finding a great place to eat. Check out the North End.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Overall, the food on campus is a lot better than most schools. It's all about personal preference.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's nice to have such a variety of options within walking distance. Could have better student deals or cheaper prices.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I would say it is much better than other places around. Even compared to schools around the country.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's a city. There is always a good variety of food in the city. And it's Boston so it's small and things are easy to get to. There are a lot of nice places to eat around Coolidge Corner and I like to go to Chinatown a lot for cheap food. Prices range from cheap to extremely expensive. I'm not very rich so I generally stick to the dining hall.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Honestly, since its campus food, the food is really not that bad. There's 3 dining halls: West, Warren, and Bay State. Warren has the best pizza and bread pudding. Bay State has the most options. I don't know much about West but I hear it has good burgers. Make a Difference Mondays are the worst but there's the GSU that accepts dining points and is just a food court so you know what you're gonna get. I love loose leafs, especially when there's avocado. mmm salad.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Boston has a ton of ethnic dining options and especially asian restaurants very close to campus.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: We have really nice dining facilities and the food is really good most of the time. Buick street market is great, but WAY too expensive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Boston is a spectacular city. Enough said.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The best dining hall food in the country. Gourmet chefs and a buffet for every meal... MIT kids tried to make fake IDs just to sneak in to get our food. Only issue is it's pricey... but so worth it
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: It's amazing. There are so many great restaurants and cafes in the area.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Compared to other schools it's really great but it's still dining hall food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: One thing I love about BU is definitely the food!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: North end is just a short T ride away!!!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Again, this depends on where you go. Warren isn't very good: if you always eat at Warren, your view will be kind of pessimistic. Bay State is always delicious, and the dining point system works extremely well.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Such a big city, many restaurants and places to go nearby
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Too many specialty/random international food stations
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: We have pretty great food options. Very rarely do I feel like there is nothing to eat. You can go to the dining hall or to the GSU or order pizza.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: LOTS of great places to eat all around Boston. Right by campus there is Noodle St., Scoozi's, Chipotle, Crispy Crepes Cafe, Jimmy John's, etc. and around Boston there are so many options and types of foods in every neighborhood it's fun to explore it all! Costs depend on where you are going. The greasy pizza joint in Allston will cost you a couple bucks while that nice Italian place at the North End will put a dent in the wallet.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Best dining plan to get is the 250 plan because you get a lot of dining points you can spend at the GSU (best food) and places like Starbucks and Einsteins. You won't want to eat at the dining hall often enough to have the dining hall plans. Bay State is the newer dining hall that is probably the nicest, but small portions. Warren food isn't the best, but it's homey. Definitely take advantage of being able to use dining points to order Dominoes.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Lots of take out options (sandwiches, Thai, Mexican, etc.) but not much sit down.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: I'd rather eat my own food, but to be fair it's much better than any other campus' food that I've tried. Sometimes the vegan/vegetarian options are disappointing at the dining halls, but there's always the option of salad, pasta, sandwich, soup or pizza. The biggest downside is how expansive a meal plan is. Every semester I have extra meals or dining points that don't get fully refunded so I wish the minimum meals you have to purchase was lower because it's a pretty big waste financially. I actually save money cooking my own food now that I'm in apartment style.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: So many different food options it's amazing.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dinning hall food isn't terrible, for a dinning hall it's actually prepared very well. And if you're not in the mood for it there are many other options. Options included using dinning points or spending outside cash.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: So much better than my friends' schools
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: It is Boston, after all. Allston has a ton of bars and Asian restaurants, and Kenmore/Newbury/Copley have really awesome options-both high end and more chain-y places. Go farther into the city and you can get anything you want, guaranteed to be delicious!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Food is pretty great for a college. Dining plans are not cheap but it's hard to complain with the amount of options we have and the overall quality. Dining halls have a lot of foreign foods but you always have your basic pizza/sandwich/salad stuff in case you're not into any of the meals they have one day. And anywhere you can use dining points is always a winner, although there aren't a ton of places that accept them
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dining foods and options on campus is above average and convenient.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: The options of healthy/organic/ethnic foods, are endless. The convenience of ordering food from local supermarkets, and having it deliver to your doorstep, for a minimal cost, is an added plus!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The few times I ate on campus, food was okay.  Cannot give many details on the campus food because i mainly cook my own meals, in my apt,
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: It's definitely not bad food, just have to be careful to not indulge in too much junk food (cookies, pizza, ice cream, fries, etc) as it's very readily available at almost any time of day and in any dining hall. With as much junk food though, there's plenty of fresher options like salad bars and sandwich stations.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Boston has so much to offer because the city is such a melting pot of cultures and people! I have loved every off campus dining experience I have had. Although some places can be expensive, you can always find more affordable places.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I have not gone anywhere with student discounts. Any type of food is available a subway ride away. I have even gone to a 24 hour Italian Bakery in the ealy morning hours. All prices are available (from fast food to gourmet dining). I have no complaints!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I don't like the fact that Sunday is breakfast all day (because I am not a breakfast fanatic). Other than that, there is every option under the sun and the food is delicious...usually.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are a lot of restaurants and diners at Kenmore Square and Fenway Park. Also, there are excellent asian cuisines in Harvard Avenue. Foods are overall not that expensive, and the restaurants are easy to get to, because there are subway stops every two block.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Best college food I know of.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Only con is the cost
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: You get sick of the food after a while
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Lots of choices since Boston is a college town, but everything is still pretty expensive
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Way too many "specialty stations" - all for that, but it's annoying that their accomodations limit the majority's options
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Many Asian options, could use more late-night
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: There are lots of yummy, various and convenient options!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Marciano's is the best dining hall besides West
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Its not too shabby but i dont have that much of a opinion about it to get too complex on it.
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: This is Boston, so finding a different place to eat every night isn't hard. The best places near campus are Sunset Cantina and T Anthony's. Sunset has the best nachos ever and T Anthony's is open pretty late. If you're looking for something fancier, the North End is where it's at.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Boston University has a great food selection. It's easy to get used to and think it isn't all that great, but as far as campus food goes, it's pretty excellent. The best place to eat is Bay State because it has the largest variety of options. Every dining hall has gluten-free and vegetarian options, so there is something for everyone. I believe if you are gluten-free they have a selection of snacks t grab in the dining hall exclusive to gluten-free students. you just have to call the dining services and have them allow your card to swipe into the room.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I have experienced the best dining options since I have lived in Boston. Boston has something for everyone!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Lots of diverse, great dining options...most reasonably priced
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: overall Boston doesnt have the best food, but the combo of having Otto's pizza, chipotle, thai places and a grocery store all along Comm Ave was good enough for those nights when I just couldnt stand the dining hall anymore
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Many dining options, Bay State is the best, but far from my dorm.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are numerous restaurants and take-out places within walking distance, and they are all very good!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The price is ok, the food is ok too.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I don't go off campus very much for food. When I do, food from places in the North End (especially Italian) is delicious. Also, the seafood selection here is amazing.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The food that BU serves is overall good, but once you start thinking about the cost you're paying, it makes you cringe..
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Off campus dining has many delicious options but they aren't very convenient to the campus and can be pricey.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's expensive at most places, but you can't argue with the quality.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: We have a lot of food options
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: You're in a city so if you can dream it and follow your phones GPS to the address it exists. There are tons of options to pick from. Some are right in campus others you have to commute to get to, but there are endless options. Many places have really great local brews too which is fun to try.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: It depends on the dining hall but I can usually leave the dining hall satisfied.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Boston is a food center. There's so many places to eat. You can never not find the next place to eat. It's simply a yelp away.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Boston University has three dining halls on its campus-- one on the eastern side, one on the west, and one in the middle. The eastern dining hall is the newest and nicest, and it includes a variety of vegetarian/vegan/gluten free options. BU also has multiple late-night options, a food court in the student union building, and other places to buy snacks with dining points. I found the number of meals, guest meals, and dining points provided to be more than ample and the quality and variety of food to be fantastic.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Dining halls are pretty great, and BU had a reputation for having some really awesome health/veg/vegan options. I was usually really satisfied and never left hungry. The GSU is a great place to use convenience points.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Lots of dining hall  and food options. The dining hall is also actively seeking student feedback to make things even better.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There are a lot of options in Boston, but things are a little expensive.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The new facilities are great, but the quality of the food is just ok.  The fresh fruits and vegetables aren't very abundant which doesn't make for great healthy options.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There isn't too much of an emphasis on fresh, local or organic fare. It's a struggle to find something that is actually healthy within a walking distance.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: I like Warren and Bay State for dining halls. Warren at lunch time is overcrowded along with the GSU. The dining hall menus repeat often and get old by the end of the semester. Majority if the food is good though. I feel the dining halls are overpriced.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Cost is one downfall because a lot of the restaurants don't have student discounts so it can get expensive but the food is really good. I have noticed that the cleanliness of the places is very poor. By this I mean that the employees don't wash their hands, or use clean utensils, or have clean facilities. Its shocking that there hasn't been more people getting sick because of how dirty these employers are in these food places.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: You're  in Boston there are tons of restaurants to fit anyone's dietary needs. A variety of cuisines are at your disposal
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: off campus dining is good and since we're in Boston there's a lot of variety and always a lot of options
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: You're in Boston. It is not hard at all to hop on the T or walk to a quality restaurant.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Food at BU is the best. Anyone who complains probably lives at Warren or OD'ed on dining hall food. There are soo many options for dining hall points outside the halls (subway, starbucks, panda express,  jamba juice, pinkberry, dominoes, cane's, etc) that most people get the 250 plan (least meals, most points).
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The food options in Boston are amazing. Everything is delicious!
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: Over the summer I have actually missed campus dining... and my mom's cooking isnt even bad!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Since we're in a city there's tons of options. The good ones cost money and as a college student you're probably not going to be eating out very much
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Live in city so theres always something
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: A lot of international/ethnic food is served in this area. Especially chinese and indian
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are great places off-campus to eat, catering to most cultures that attend BU.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Having a city surround the campus means there are a ton of restaurants, cafes, delivery options. I have never heard of a place offering student discounts, but there are somewhat cheap options available for pizza and burgers. Vegan options are not unheard of and there are three vegan restaurants just a bike or bus ride away. Definitely check out Fomu for their amazing vegan hard ice cream and the vegan Chinese restaurant Grasshopper. There are a variety of ethnic food restaurants in Boston including Brazilian and Thai food. There are also pricey, nice places for your parents to take you or for you to take a date.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: We are in the middle of Boston, there are so many restaurants either a T ride or a walk away. What more could you ask for?
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Whatever you're craving can be found somewhere nearby.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There's a lot of options in Kenmore/Fenway and also a lot on the other side in Allston. There are different ethnic options, and various types of foods.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Campus dining at BU is definitely the best at any college that I visited.  That being said, its still not home cooking and the dining plans are pricey.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: it's extremely overpriced and I have trouble finding options in the dining hall that I like
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are numerous off-campus dining options that are on campus or right by campus, and lots of options in the city.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Lots of places to eat!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review:
Just hop on the B Green line that runs through BU campus and you can be dropped in front of a number of restaurants from 5 star dining to Mom n Pop shops! For example, only 3 stops away from Kenmore is the highly rated Top of the Hub. While slightly pricy (and rightly so), this restaurant on the 52nd floor of the Prudential Tower makes for a memorable evening with the BEST view in Boston. Take the Greenline all the way to Government Center and you're in the North End with Italian restaurants upon Italian restaurants, top-rated bakeries, and a lively social scene. 

Boston is a great place to be a foodie, but what makes it THE city to try new foods is the annual Restaurant Week. This occurs once or twice a year for a few days. Selected restaurants construct Prix Fix menus where they slash their prices on their best dishes, creating both a delicious and affordable meal for even broke college students!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review:
While I have to admit our food is pretty decent, certain aspects make the dining plans not worth it: costs, Make A Difference Monday, and early closings.

The dining plan costs increases every year but why? We don't know. 

Make a Difference Monday is still present...again, why? As the saying goes, students feel like the only "difference" it makes is in our waistlines (because people don't eat in dining halls on these days). 

Early closings: oh my. It's difficult to find food when the dining hall closes the entire first floor, it's a Friday during Lent (so no meat), and the cereals and fruits are gone....sort of inconvenient. 

Honestly, everything could be dealt with if the prices would just stop going up!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Great food everywhere. Most places are affordable unless you're looking for a fancy five-star restaurant.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Since the entire city of Boston is "off-campus", the dining options are endless. Students often eat out in Allston, Brookline, Cambridge, and downtown areas like the North End (Italian) and Chinatown.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Overall the variety and quality of BU dining options are good. Warren is pretty standard and west is barely above average, but Bay State is exceptional and has interesting theme nights like "Chocolate Night" and visiting chef series that improve the quality of the food. The GSU has some great options and using convenience points to order Dominoes is a late night blessing. Other late night options include Warren late night (pretty junk food-y, but open until 2am) and Bay State late night, which closes at 11 usually but is a sit-down restaurant with sweet and savory crepes, pizzas, wings, salads, etc. Lobster night is overrated and Make a Difference Monday is the bane of everyone's existence.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are a ton of options, but the best ones are more expensive than average (Newbury Street). For slightly cheaper, many of the Thai places lining Comm ave are surprisingly good. There's always the fast food/chain options as well, which  are plentiful.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Vegetarian option is ALWAYS tofu. The tofu ALWAYS tastes bad.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I've never heard of any off-campus dining that offered student discounts, but I still love the occasional off-campus dinner or lunch break. Nothing seems too chain at all, you can find all kinds of restaurants if you take the time to explore the city.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Somewhat expensive and also boring.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I am a picky eater,  so... my options are somewhat limited, stick mostly to campus food
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are plenty of options, from chinese food to subway.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Lots of fast food type places.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's Boston; what else do you expect?
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: What can I say it is Boston, we have everything and anything you are looking for.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There is a large variety of dining options mixed into the campus, and even more dining options if you're willing to walk a little ways.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I go to school at the University of Boston.  Boston has a variety of dining options to fit all tastes and budgets.  There are places where you can get pizza by the slice, chain restaurants, and local eateries.  The food ranges from Chinese to Indian to Italian to local fare.  It is a great place to go to school and to explore other cultures and their food.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I love the food and I'm convinced that I am gaining so much weight from it. However, the walking should balance it out very soon.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: being in the city offers a tremendous amounts of restaurants. you can go eat any kinds of food that range from all different prices. also many cafe and study areas off campus
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: So many great places to eat. You will never get bored of the food choices.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: great variety ! The restaurants can be very expensive
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: There are many acceptable upscale restaurants around the Boston area. There is also Noodle St on Comm Ave which is a great place, and the many little restaurants along Comm Ave add life to this college's campus.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There is so much diversity.  I can go a few blocks of my dorm and have access to very diverse restaurants.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Very nice facilities with decent selection
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The bookstore offers a coupon book filled with places of where to dine and receive discounts. Usually you show your student ID and they offer a discount. It is not major, but it helps save a few dollars. Plenty of places and variety choose from.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: For a big school, campus dining is great! It offers a lot of options including vegan/vegetarian on "Make-A-Difference-Mondays." There are three big dining halls throughout campus which might get crowded depending on what time you go. The food is pretty good quality, not the best, but it's good enough. There's also a food court in the GSU which offers good places to eat for dining points. Late night food is also offered and is another great way to use dining points. Starbucks is the best because it is conveniently located at SMG and you can use dining points to grab some coffee or breakfast.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I know I'm spoiled. BU has great dining halls with crazy variety and good food. However, I can be picky, and BU tends to overdo it a bit with the healthy options for me. Beware of Make A Difference Monday.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Boston. There are plenty of restaurants around. Lots of small little diners, but also lots of chains. Take your pick.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Since we live in Boston, there are tons of unique restaurants everywhere. There are also local markets, super markets, and health food stores in many locations.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There is one dining hall in west campus, two in east, and one in central. Overall, they have many more options than other schools. However, the dining plan is around $4000 no matter what plan you're on. A meal swipe is typically $15 if you were using dining points, and it's not worth that.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are many options from fast food to organic to ethnic restaurants.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Yummy, but pricey! Many options though.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The food is just generally good, but Bay State is the best.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are a lot of places to eat, usually ends at midnight and the costs are pretty high. Mostly unhealthy food. Student discounts is just tax off.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Boston University has amazing dining halls.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: You have to do a bit of walking but it's totally worth it
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: It's pretty good compared to other schools. The chefs pair up with the school of nutrition so it's usually healthy. Best dining hall is 100 Bay State Rd (aka Marciano Commons), GSU is good but expensive, there is late night all over. I recommend Rize Bakery (Basement of 100 Bay State. And as of now Insomnia Cookies delivers until 3 am
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: It's in a city, therefore it's pretty abundant.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: as far as "mass feeding" goes the dining hall food at BU is good. there's been a push in recent years for healthier options ("Sergeant's Choice") which is good and there's always a vegetarian option for hot meal as well as sandwiches and salads. The GSU food court area is great with a bunch of restaurants and reasonably priced meals. I'd recommend a dining plan with meals and points so you have more options of where to eat.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: The off-campus dining is good.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Three different dining halls, and a cafeteria that accepts dining points. Lots of variety, so you never really get sick of the food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are many restaurants and food trucks and things around or off campus. some are right next door, or some could be down the street or miles away. The quality is generally superb and they usually have some student discounts. The prices may reach the high end at times in some places.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Started off very good, but devolved a bit. Comparatively very good, but can be much better. There is a good variety, but not good quality in the variety.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Nice variety, prices high (it is Boston!)
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Oh the wonders of a meal plan! There are so many options for food on-campus that it might just take you a semester to find them all. Make sure you pick a plan that offers dining points (the 250 plan worked very well for me). Here's a quick explanation: Dining points are like money, except you have to spend it on on-campus retail locations like Buick Street Market (a great mini grocery), Dunkin Donuts, Starbucks, Late Night Kitchen (restaurant under 100 Bay State) and even to order pizza from Dominoes or Pizza Hut. Check out bu.edu/dining to find out what other options you have - it will blow your mind! The dining hall food isn't that bad either. Except for a lack of seasoning on their meats (probably a health standard) the dining halls do quite well for themselves and have different dishes every day. Convenience points are what the title implies - convenient, but what they really are is just another way BU tries to grab for money from you. If you're paying 4.5K for a meal plan why should you spend extra money for food? Exactly, you shouldn't. So keep your hard earned money in your pocket and when the time comes to actually buy something from the "Convenience Store" aka on-campus mini corner store, just use your own money.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There is a large variety of food, reasonably priced.  Each restaurant seems to have plenty of seating, allowing for group products to be done outside of the library.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There are three main dining halls on campus and one food court, each offering many varieties of food options. Dining points also help pay for ordering pizza and late night kitchens which the students love.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: In the city of Boston there are tons of options for dining and you easily be able to find anything you might be craving.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: West Is Best – the food on campus has super high ratings and is better than all the other colleges that i visited, glad to be living in west campus where the food is the best :)
Food.Author: College Junior
